importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The FAA imposed a 38-plane-per-month production cap on Boeing's 737 MAX in January 2024, following safety concerns.
The production cap was lifted on October 17, 2025, allowing Boeing to increase 737 MAX output to 42 planes per month.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period from January 2024 to the cap's lifting in 2025 marks the duration of the production restriction due to safety concerns.

keyTakeAways: The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) has lifted a 38-plane-per-month production cap on the Boeing 737 MAX, allowing increased output to 42 planes per month.
The cap was initially imposed in January 2024 after a mid-air emergency involving a new Alaska Airlines 737 MAX 9 that was missing four key bolts.
The FAA conducted extensive reviews of Boeing’s production lines to ensure that the safety and quality of the aircraft remain intact during the rate increase.
Boeing CEO Kelly Ortberg was contacted by FAA Administrator Bryan Bedford to confirm the production increase is feasible and safe.
Boeing plans to immediately begin producing 737 MAX aircraft at the new rate of 42 per month.
The decision reflects progress in restoring trust between Boeing, regulators, and the public following a major safety crisis.

namedEntities.name: Boeing
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A U.S. aerospace manufacturer and aircraft planemaker
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Boeing is central to the article as the company whose production rate is being increased after a safety crisis and regulatory oversight.

namedEntities.name: 737 MAX
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A model of commercial jet aircraft produced by Boeing
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The 737 MAX is the specific aircraft model involved in the safety incident and production cap that is now being lifted.

namedEntities.name: Federal Aviation Administration (FAA)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: U.S. government agency responsible for aviation safety regulations
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The FAA imposed and now lifted the production cap, demonstrating regulatory oversight and safety review in response to aviation incidents.

namedEntities.name: Alaska Airlines
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Alaska Airlines operated a 737 MAX 9 involved in the 2024 mid-air emergency that triggered the production cap.

namedEntities.name: Kelly Ortberg
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: As Boeing’s CEO, Kelly Ortberg was directly involved in communicating the company’s readiness and commitment to safety during the production increase.

namedEntities.name: Bryan Bedford
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Bryan Bedford led the FAA's safety review process and confirmed the production increase with Boeing’s CEO, highlighting regulatory engagement.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) has lifted a 38-plane-per-month production cap on Boeing’s 737 MAX, allowing the company to increase output to 42 planes per month. This decision follows a safety incident in 2024 involving an Alaska Airlines 737 MAX 9 that was missing four key bolts, which led to the initial cap. The FAA conducted extensive safety reviews of Boeing’s production lines to ensure the new rate maintains high standards of safety and quality. Boeing CEO Kelly Ortberg was contacted by FAA Administrator Bryan Bedford to confirm the feasibility of the increase. The move marks a significant recovery step for Boeing after its 2018-2024 safety crisis, restoring confidence in both the aircraft and production processes.
title: Boeing can hike 737 MAX production to 42 planes per month, FAA says
